text: Patient: Well I mean is there a benefit to taking the pain medication? Doctor: Yeah, you’d be more functional. Patient: Well I’m functionable. Family Member: But you’re in pain. Patient: Well then I also feel that if I’m masking the pain too much, then I’m overextending myself. Or maybe I shouldn’t be. Doctor: Oh well, set your activity level and don’t exceed it. Patient: Then I don’t need pain medication. Family Member: Yeah, but you can’t walk around in the stores; you can’t walk around for any length of time. If we go to Florida in February, you have to be able to walk on the beach; you aren’t going to be able to - Patient: But then again, if I’m taking pain medication to hide that pain, is that a good idea because then I’m gonna overextend myself. Doctor: I am so not going to get in the middle of this discussion with you two. You know the answer. If you need to go somewhere and be functional, go take your medication. You’re just chillaxing in front of the television, you’re probably just fine. Family Member: Right. Doctor: I’m sure you over-did it. I should have gone by your house and taken that darned ladder. I didn’t.

text: Patient: Let me ask you this here. Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: What is the effects of a seizure? Doctor: Well a seizure is exactly what you see on TV you know when your brain is too hyperactive and you’re kind of going like this and you can’t control it. Patient: Okay so what do we do? And the reason why… Doctor: If that happens she’s calling nine one one, but it’s a percent chance less than that. Okay. Patient: Okay then let me ask you this here doc. Let me ask you this here. If I had a seizure Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: right now Doctor: Yeah. Patient: and we ain’t in the hospital. Doctor: Okay. Patient: What would you do to accommodate me with the seizure other than dialing nine one one?

text: Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: and then we check you for a period of a year because we want to know. Same thing like the flu shot is only good for a finite time, right, like this much time is in it. Well, we know every year you have to re-up on that flu shot. We have no idea about this medicine. It’s a one and done. So, our patient’s sign up for, hey I wonder what’s going on in nine months or a year after the fact. So, we hope you participate in that because it’s important for us to know so that’s one treatment option. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: Now, after we do that, a month after that I rescan you again because by then it’s already about ten, twelve weeks that’s passed, almost three months, and then we see what the scans are when they’re done; if they’re worse, the same, or sort of the same. So, that’s all your two choices. Um, and if it’s not or if your PSA is now going whoa, it’s really up there, we normally then will say okay, we either got to commit to chemo Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: or pills. Now, chemo and pills are FDA approved. Kind of just like when you had the chemo before Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: FDA approved. We would do a different chemo. I wouldn’t repeat the same chemo but it’s a cousin drug so it’s still once every three weeks just like before. Okay, the pills are four pills a day every day. Patient: For the rest of your life? Doctor: Yeah, until it stops working, which at some point after a couple years it sort of poops out and stops working. So, we have studies there too. So, you got to say okay, what’s this study with the chemo. Well, you know in Oncology we love to combine stuff so the study is either the pill or chemo plus the pill. I know. So, it’s a win-win in the sense that you either get the pill get the pill that you were going to get anyways Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: or you actually get the double whammy and you get the pill and Patient: and the chemo.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And, you know, is it a mail-order thing? And if it’s crazy, is there a different thing we can do? text: Patient: Yeah, just out of the blue. It last for a few minutes and then stops. Doctor: Okay, on an average day how many times does that happen or is it not every day? Patient: When I’ve noticed it, it might be once or twice a day. Doctor: Okay, all right. Usually not at night, usually during the day. Patient: No, no. Well it could be the stress or the activity that’s happening in church that might push my level. Doctor: Well your testosterone level is still low. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And it’s creeping up, so about three or four months ago twice in the thirties. The normal testosterone for a man of your age would be around a hundred and fifty or two hundred. When we checked your last blood test about two weeks ago it had gone up to fifty-eight. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So it’s slowly increasing. Patient: Right. Doctor: That would mean at least in theory that your fatigue should begin to get better, although the increase has been very recent, so it may not have given your body the time to adjust to that higher level of testosterone. And with time if you remain off of the hormone therapy like you’re currently doing despite your age it may continue to increase further. Patient: Uh huh.

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: But I want to make sure on the studies everybody gets pictures of the same time points so that we can see when the cancer changes. Patient: And another question that I have. At one point we talked to acupuncturist and he said he can help through acupuncture with peeing problems. So and I was thinking we’d go on the day when we take the catheter our, but now I’m thinking maybe I should wait. And now if that is okay, see if that may be some additional help. Doctor: I don’t know. I think it’s reasonable to try. You know most acupuncturists will ask you about your current situation – Patient: Right. Doctor: - and see how well it would help. You know my worry is you know if you’re spending money on that then how does it help? You know if they are doing it and you get the catheter out is it because of my drug or because they gave you, you know acupuncture and how long you paid them? Patient: Yeah, right. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And so those are all issues that you’ve got to sort out. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: How do you know it’s working? Family Member: I think that we should probably wait until catheter is out.

text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And also… Family Member: And does he do it here in the office with you guys? Doctor: So typically it’s an injection. Patient: Um hum. text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. It comes with side effects because it’s never nothing without nothing. Patient: What is the side effects? Doctor: Number one, two and three is tiredness. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And tiredness isn’t that your brain isn’t functioning, functioning great. Patient: Just physically tired? Doctor: Physically tired and it’s a weirder tired not like you worked out in the yard for twelve hours and can’t do much, it’s just no get up and go. If that happens, we take a break and we reduce the medicine dose. Patient: Let me ask you something doc. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Can we, can we provide a pill that would give me a little, like a vitamin that would give me a little energy? Doctor: No I think the issue of you not having as much energy is that your cancer is starting to, sorry that your thing is starting to break through slowly, Patient: Right.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
